headline.main: 2 Downing Street Neighbors in Need of a Fence

lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Tony Blair has traveled the world keeping the antiterror war coalition united and focused on a common enemy, but at home his powerful second in command, Gordon Brown, the chancellor of the exchequer, has plunged his government into open combat. ''When you have two people that aren't working together, and that's the prime minister and the chancellor, it doesn't lead to positive, easy decision-making,'' Mo Mowlam, a former member of Mr. Blair's cabinet, said over the weekend in a BBC interview that reignited a long-simmering feud at the heart of the Blair government. ''You know there's a battle going on, and people go to one side or the other, and I think that is just crippling for government.''
